./.title: Introduction
./.body:
learnml

Write machine learning algorithms from zero for self-learning.
All algorithm codes are implemented in Python with friendly comments and easier to understand how they works.

supervised/logistic_regression.html.title: Logistic regression
supervised/logistic_regression.html.body:
Logistic regression
References

CS229 Lecture notes (pdf).
Logistic Regression

Objective
The logistic regression can be understood simply as finding the w{w}w parameters that best fit:
y={1ϕ(z)≥0.50else
{y={\begin{cases}1& \phi(z) \ge 0.5 \\0&{\text{else}}\end{cases}}}
y={10​ϕ(z)≥0.5else​
the logistic function
ϕ(z)=11+e−z,
\phi(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}},
ϕ(z)=1+e−z1​,
where
z=w0x0+w1x1+...+wmxm=∑j=0mwjxj=wTx.
z = w_0x_0 + w_1x_1 + ... + w_mx_m = \sum_{j=0}^{m} w_j x_j= \mathbf{w}^T\mathbf{x}.
z=w0​x0​+w1​x1​+...+wm​xm​=j=0∑m​wj​xj​=wTx.
Solution
Objective Function Log-Likelihood
We write the likelihood as
L(w)=P(y∣x;w)=∏i=1nP(y(i)∣x(i);w)=∏i=1n(ϕ(z(i)))y(i)(1−ϕ(z(i)))1−y(i),
L(\mathbf{w}) = P(\mathbf{y} \mid \mathbf{x};\mathbf{w}) = \prod_{i=1}^{n} P\big(y^{(i)} \mid x^{(i)}; \mathbf{w}\big) = \prod^{n}_{i=1}\bigg(\phi\big(z^{(i)}\big)\bigg)^{y^{(i)}} \bigg(1-\phi\big(z^{(i)}\big)\bigg)^{1-y^{(i)}},
L(w)=P(y∣x;w)=i=1∏n​P(y(i)∣x(i);w)=i=1∏n​(ϕ(z(i)))y(i)(1−ϕ(z(i)))1−y(i),
maximize the (natural) log of this equation, which is called the log-likelihood function:
l(w)=log⁡L(w)=∑i=1ny(i)log⁡(ϕ(z(i)))+(1−y(i))log⁡(1−ϕ(z(i)))
l(\mathbf{w}) = \log L(\mathbf{w}) = \sum^{n}_{i=1} y^{(i)} \log \bigg(\phi\big(z^{(i)}\big)\bigg) + \big( 1 - y^{(i)}\big) \log \big(1-\phi\big(z^{(i)}\big)\big)
l(w)=logL(w)=i=1∑n​y(i)log(ϕ(z(i)))+(1−y(i))log(1−ϕ(z(i)))
Objective Function Logistic Cost Function
we rewrite the log-likelihood as:
J(w)=∑i=1m−y(i)log(ϕ(z(i)))−(1−y(i))log(1−ϕ(z(i)))
J(\mathbf{w}) = \sum_{i=1}^{m} - y^{(i)} log \bigg( \phi\big(z^{(i)}\big) \bigg) - \big(1 - y^{(i)}\big) log\bigg(1-\phi\big(z^{(i)}\big)\bigg)
J(w)=i=1∑m​−y(i)log(ϕ(z(i)))−(1−y(i))log(1−ϕ(z(i)))
∂∂wjl(w)=(y1ϕ(z)−(1−y)11−ϕ(z))∂∂wjϕ(z)
\frac{\partial}{\partial w_j} l(\mathbf{w}) = \bigg(y \frac{1}{\phi(z)} - (1-y) \frac{1}{1-\phi{(z)}} \bigg) \frac{\partial}{\partial w_j}\phi(z)
∂wj​∂​l(w)=(yϕ(z)1​−(1−y)1−ϕ(z)1​)∂wj​∂​ϕ(z)
compute the partial derivative of the sigmoid function, which will come in handy later:
∂∂zϕ(z)=∂∂z11+e−z=1(1+e−z)2e−z=11+e−z(1−11+e−z)=ϕ(z)(1−ϕ(z))
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \phi(z) = \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \frac{1}{1+e^{-z}} \\\\
&= \frac{1}{(1 + e^{-z})^{2}} e^{-z}\\\\
&= \frac{1}{1+e^{-z}} \bigg(1 - \frac{1}{1+e^{-z}} \bigg)\\\\
&= \phi(z)\big(1-\phi(z)\big)
\end{aligned}
​∂z∂​ϕ(z)=∂z∂​1+e−z1​=(1+e−z)21​e−z=1+e−z1​(1−1+e−z1​)=ϕ(z)(1−ϕ(z))​
re-substitute
∂∂zϕ(z)=ϕ(z)(1−ϕ(z))
\frac{\partial}{\partial z} \phi(z) = \phi(z) \big(1 - \phi(z)\big)
∂z∂​ϕ(z)=ϕ(z)(1−ϕ(z))
back into in the log-likelihood partial derivative equation and obtain the equation shown below:
(y1ϕ(z)−(1−y)11−ϕ(z))∂∂wjϕ(z)=(y1ϕ(z)−(1−y)11−ϕ(z))ϕ(z)(1−ϕ(z))∂∂wjz=(y(1−ϕ(z))−(1−y)ϕ(z))xj=(y−ϕ(z))xj
\begin{aligned}
& \bigg(y \frac{1}{\phi{(z)}} - (1 - y) \frac{1}{1 - \phi(z)} \bigg) \frac{\partial}{\partial w_j} \phi(z) \\\\
&= \bigg(y \frac{1}{\phi{(z)}} - (1 - y) \frac{1}{1 - \phi(z)} \bigg) \phi(z) \big(1 - \phi(z)\big) \frac{\partial}{\partial w_j}z\\\\
&= \big(y(1-\phi(z)\big) - (1 - y) \phi(z)\big)x_j\\\\
&= \big(y - \phi(z)\big)x_j
\end{aligned}
​(yϕ(z)1​−(1−y)1−ϕ(z)1​)∂wj​∂​ϕ(z)=(yϕ(z)1​−(1−y)1−ϕ(z)1​)ϕ(z)(1−ϕ(z))∂wj​∂​z=(y(1−ϕ(z))−(1−y)ϕ(z))xj​=(y−ϕ(z))xj​​
we add a coefficient, the learning rate η to the weight update:
wj:=wj+η∂∂wjl(w)wj:=wj+η∑i=1n(y(i)−ϕ(z(i)))xj(i)
\begin{aligned}
& w_j := w_j + \eta \frac{\partial}{\partial w_j} l(\mathbf{w})\\\\
& w_j := w_j + \eta \sum^{n}_{i=1} \big( y^{(i)} - \phi\big(z^{(i)}\big)\big)x_j^{(i)}
\end{aligned}
​wj​:=wj​+η∂wj​∂​l(w)wj​:=wj​+ηi=1∑n​(y(i)−ϕ(z(i)))xj(i)​​
Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) is a simple yet very efficient approach to discriminative learning of linear classifiers under convex loss functions such as Logistic Regression. 
minimize logistic cost function J()J()J() via gradient descent in order to learn the logistic regression model.
Δwj=−η∂J∂wj=−η∑i=1n(y(i)−ϕ(z(i))x(i))
\begin{aligned}
& \Delta{w_j} = -\eta \frac{\partial J}{\partial w_j} \\
& = - \eta \sum_{i=1}^{n}\big(y^{(i)} - \phi\big(z^{(i)}\big) x^{(i)} \big)
\end{aligned}
​Δwj​=−η∂wj​∂J​=−ηi=1∑n​(y(i)−ϕ(z(i))x(i))​
Initialize
Choose an initial vector of parameters w{w}w and learning rate η{\eta}η.
self.w = np.zeros(X.shape[1])

Caculate y_pred
For i=1,2,...,n{i=1,2,...,n}i=1,2,...,n, do:
scores = np.dot(X, self.w)
y_pred = self.sigmoid(scores)

w:=w−η∇Qi(w).
{\!w:=w-\eta \nabla Q_{i}(w).}
w:=w−η∇Qi​(w).
Caculate www
in logistic regression
wnew=wold−η(y^−y)X
w_{new}=w_{old}-\eta(\hat{y}-y)X
wnew​=wold​−η(y^​−y)X
grad_w = (y_pred - y).dot(X)
self.w -= self.learning_rate * grad_w

supervised/linear_regression.html.title: Linear Regression
supervised/linear_regression.html.body:
Linear Regression
References

G. Strang, Linear Algebra and Its Applications (book).
Linear Least Squares, Projection, Pseudoinverses (pdf).

Objective
In statistics, linear regression is a linear approach to modelling the relationship between a scalar response (or dependent variable) and one or more explanatory variables (or independent variables).
Solve β{\beta}β:
Xβ=y
X{\beta} = y
Xβ=y
Solution
LLS
Linear least squares (LLS) is the least squares approximation of linear functions to data.
In regression, we desire to predict the target with the inputs. In a least squares sense, the goal is to find β{\beta}β which minimizes:
min⁡β∥y−Xβ∣∣2
\min _{\beta}\|y-X{\beta}||^{2}
βmin​∥y−Xβ∣∣2
OLS
Ordinary least squares (OLS) is the most common estimator.
The OLS method minimizes the sum of squared residuals, and leads to a closed-form expression for the estimated value of the unknown parameter vector βββ:
Xβ=y
X{\beta} = y
Xβ=y
XTXβ=XTy
X^T X {\beta} = X^T y
XTXβ=XTy
β=(X⊤X)−1XTy
{\beta} = (X^{\top}X)^{-1} X^T y
β=(X⊤X)−1XTy
Pseudo-inverse
The pseudo-inverse of a matrix A, denoted  A+A^+A+, is defined as: “the matrix that ‘solves’ [the least-squares problem]  Ax=bAx = bAx=b,” i.e., if  xˉ\bar{x}xˉ  is said solution, then  A+A^+A+  is that matrix such that  xˉ=A+b.\bar{x} = A^+b.xˉ=A+b.
A+=(ATA)−1AT
A^{+} = (A^T A)^{-1} A^T
A+=(ATA)−1AT
β{\beta}β is solved with:
β=X+y
{\beta} = X^{+}y
β=X+y
w = np.linalg.pinv(X).dot(y)

supervised/lasso_regression.html.title: Lasso Regression
supervised/lasso_regression.html.body:
Lasso Regression
References

Pathwise Coordinate Optimization (pdf).
Regularization Paths for Generalized Linear Models via Coordinate Descent.

Solution
Step 1
initialize betabetabeta，fix λ\lambdaλ value
Step 2
if intercept, update β0\beta_0β0​
β0=∑i=1n(yi−Xi,β)n
\beta _ { 0 } = \frac { \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { n } \left( y _ { i } - { X } _ { i , { \beta } } \right) } { n }
β0​=n∑i=1n​(yi​−Xi,β​)​
Step 3
while true
for i in len(β\betaβ)，update βj\beta_jβj​
βj=1X:,jTX:,jS(X:jT(y−X:,−jβ−j),λn)
\beta _ { j } = \frac { 1 } { { X } _ { : , j } ^ { T } { X } _ { : , j } } S \left( { X } _ { : j } ^ { T } \left( { y } - { X } _ { : , - j } { \beta } _ { - j } \right) , \lambda n \right)
βj​=X:,jT​X:,j​1​S(X:jT​(y−X:,−j​β−j​),λn)
beta[j] = self._S(z, gamma) / X[:, j].dot(X[:, j].T)

if intercept β0\beta_0β0​:
β0=∑i=1n(yi−Xi,β)n\beta _ { 0 } = \frac { \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { n } \left( y _ { i } - { X } _ { i , { \beta } } \right) } { n }
β0​=n∑i=1n​(yi​−Xi,β​)​
beta[0] = np.sum(y - np.dot(X[:, 1:], beta[1:])) / (X.shape[0])

soft-thresholding operator
S(β;γ)={β^−γ, if β^>0 and γ<∣β^∣β^+γ, if β^<0 and γ<∣β^∣0, if γ≥∣β^∣
\mathcal{S}(\beta ; \gamma)=\left\{\begin{array}{ll}{\hat{\beta}-\gamma,} & {\text { if } \hat{\beta}>0 \text { and } \gamma<|\hat{\beta}|} \\ {\hat{\beta}+\gamma,} & {\text { if } \hat{\beta}<0 \text { and } \gamma<|\hat{\beta}|} \\ {0,} & {\text { if } \gamma \geq|\hat{\beta}|}\end{array}\right.
S(β;γ)=⎩⎨⎧​β^​−γ,β^​+γ,0,​ if β^​>0 and γ<∣β^​∣ if β^​<0 and γ<∣β^​∣ if γ≥∣β^​∣​
if z > 0.0 and gamma < abs(z):
    return z - gamma
elif z < 0.0 and gamma < abs(z):
    return z + gamma
else:
    return 0.0

supervised/linear_discriminant_analysis..title: linear Discriminant Analysis
supervised/linear_discriminant_analysis..body:
Linear discriminant analysis
References

Fisher discriminant analysis with kernels (pdf).
Kernel Fisher Discriminant for Texture Classification (pdf).
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kernel_Fisher_discriminant_analysis
https://sebastianraschka.com/Articles/2014_python_lda.html

Objective
The goal of linear discriminant analysis is to give a large separation of the class means while also keeping the in-class variance small.

The within-class scatter matrix SWS_WSW​ is computed by the following equation:
Sw=∑i=1cSi
\mathbf {S} _{w} = \sum\limits_{i=1}^{c}  \mathbf {S} _{i}
Sw​=i=1∑c​Si​
where scatter matrix for every class
Si=∑x∈Di(x−mi)T(x−mi)
{\mathbf {S} _{i}=\sum _{x\in {\mathcal {D}}_{i}}\left(\mathbf {x} -\mathbf {m} _{i}\right)^{T}\left(\mathbf {x} -\mathbf {m} _{i}\right)}
Si​=x∈Di​∑​(x−mi​)T(x−mi​)
and mim_imi​ is the mean vector
mi=1li∑n=1lixni
{\mathbf {m} _{i}={\frac {1}{l_{i}}}\sum _{n=1}^{l_{i}}\mathbf {x} _{n}^{i}}
mi​=li​1​n=1∑li​​xni​
CiC_iCi​: label, mim_imi​: class means, lil_ili​ is the number of examples of class CiC_iCi​
So the function that needs to be maximized is:
J(w)=∣m~1−m~2∣2s~12+s~22=(wtm1−wtm2)2wtS1w+wtF2w=wt(m1−m2)(m1−m2)twwt(S1+S2)w=wTSBwwTSWw
\begin{aligned} J(\mathbf{w}) &=\frac{\left|\tilde{m}_{1}-\tilde{m}_{2}\right|^{2}}{\tilde{s}_{1}^{2}+\tilde{s}_{2}^{2}} \\ &=\frac{\left(\mathbf{w}^{t} \mathbf{m}_{1}-\mathbf{w}^{t} \mathbf{m}_{2}\right)^{2}}{\mathbf{w}^{t} \mathbf{S}_{1} \mathbf{w}+\mathbf{w}^{t} \mathbf{F}_{2} \mathbf{w}} \\ &=\frac{\mathbf{w}^{t}\left(\mathbf{m}_{1}-\mathbf{m}_{2}\right)\left(\mathbf{m}_{1}-\mathbf{m}_{2}\right)^{t} \mathbf{w}}{\mathbf{w}^{t}\left(\mathbf{S}_{1}+\mathbf{S}_{2}\right) \mathbf{w}} \\ &=\frac{\mathbf{w}^{T} \mathbf{S}_{\mathbf{B}} \mathbf{w}}{\mathbf{w}^{T} \mathbf{S}_{\mathbf{W}} \mathbf{w}} \end{aligned}
J(w)​=s~12​+s~22​∣m~1​−m~2​∣2​=wtS1​w+wtF2​w(wtm1​−wtm2​)2​=wt(S1​+S2​)wwt(m1​−m2​)(m1​−m2​)tw​=wTSW​wwTSB​w​​
Solution
Maximizing
J(w)=wTSBwwTSWw
{J(\mathbf {w} )={\frac {\mathbf {w} ^T \mathbf {S} _{B}\mathbf {w} }{\mathbf {w} ^T \mathbf {S} _{W}\mathbf {w} }}}
J(w)=wTSW​wwTSB​w​
is equivalent to maximizing
max⁡wwTSBws.t.wTSWw=1
\begin{array}{cl}{\max _{w}} & \mathbf {w} ^{\text{T}}\mathbf {S} _{B}\mathbf {w} \\ {\text {s.t.}} & \mathbf {w} ^{\text{T}}\mathbf {S} _{W}\mathbf {w} =1\end{array}
maxw​s.t.​wTSB​wwTSW​w=1​
where SB{\displaystyle \mathbf {S}_{B}}SB​ is the between-class covariance matrix and SW{\displaystyle \mathbf {S}_{W}}SW​ is the total within-class covariance matrix:
SBϕ=∑i=1cli(miϕ−mϕ)(miϕ−mϕ)T
{\mathbf {S} _{B}^{\phi }=\sum _{i=1}^{c}l_{i}(\mathbf {m} _{i}^{\phi }-\mathbf {m} ^{\phi })(\mathbf {m} _{i}^{\phi }-\mathbf {m} ^{\phi })^{\text{T}}}
SBϕ​=i=1∑c​li​(miϕ​−mϕ)(miϕ​−mϕ)T
def _S_B(self, X, y):
    labels = self._labels(y)
    n_features = self._n_features(X)
    overall_mean = np.mean(X, axis=0)
    S_B = np.empty((n_features, n_features))
    for label in labels:
        _X = X[y == label]
        _mean = np.mean(_X, axis=0)
        S_B += len(_X) * \
            (_mean - overall_mean).dot((_mean - overall_mean).T)
    return S_B

SWϕ=∑i=1c∑n=1li(ϕ(xni)−miϕ)(ϕ(xni)−miϕ)T,
{\mathbf {S} _{W}^{\phi }=\sum _{i=1}^{c}\sum _{n=1}^{l_{i}}(\phi (\mathbf {x} _{n}^{i})-\mathbf {m} _{i}^{\phi })(\phi (\mathbf {x} _{n}^{i})-\mathbf {m} _{i}^{\phi })^{\text{T}},}
SWϕ​=i=1∑c​n=1∑li​​(ϕ(xni​)−miϕ​)(ϕ(xni​)−miϕ​)T,
def _S_W(self, X, y):
    labels = self._labels(y)
    n_features = self._n_features(X)
    S_W = np.empty((n_features, n_features))
    for label in labels:
        _X = X[y == label]
        S_W += (len(_X) - 1) * covariance_matrix(_X)
    return S_W

equivalent to maximizing I(w,λ)=wTSBw−λ(wTSWw−1){\displaystyle I(\mathbf {w} ,\lambda )=\mathbf {w} ^{\text{T}}\mathbf {S} _{B}\mathbf {w} -\lambda (\mathbf {w} ^{\text{T}}\mathbf {S} _{W}\mathbf {w} -1)}I(w,λ)=wTSB​w−λ(wTSW​w−1), where λ{\displaystyle \lambda }λ is the Lagrange multiplier.
taking dIdw=0{\displaystyle {\frac {dI}{d\mathbf {w} }}=\mathbf {0} }dwdI​=0 yields:
SBw−λSWw=0,
{\displaystyle \mathbf {S} _{B}\mathbf {w} -\lambda \mathbf {S} _{W}\mathbf {w} =\mathbf {0} ,}
SB​w−λSW​w=0,
SW−1SBw=λw
\mathbf {S} _{W}^{-1} \mathbf {S} _{B} \mathbf {w}=\lambda \mathbf w
SW−1​SB​w=λw
Solve the generalized eigenvalue problem for the matrix SW−1SB\mathbf {S} _{W}^{-1} \mathbf {S} _{B}SW−1​SB​ to obtain the linear discriminants.
Kernel Trick
The kernel trick can be used and the goal of multi-class KFD becomes:
A∗=argmax⁡A=∣ATMA∣∣ATNA∣,
{\mathbf {A} ^{*}={\underset {\mathbf {A} }{\operatorname {argmax} }}={\frac {\left|\mathbf {A} ^{\text{T}}\mathbf {M} \mathbf {A} \right|}{\left|\mathbf {A} ^{\text{T}}\mathbf {N} \mathbf {A} \right|}},}
A∗=Aargmax​=∣ATNA∣∣∣​ATMA∣∣​​,
Where A=[α1,…,αc−1]{\displaystyle A=[\mathbf {\alpha } _{1},\ldots ,\mathbf {\alpha } _{c-1}]}A=[α1​,…,αc−1​] and:
M=∑j=1clj(Mj−M∗)(Mj−M∗)TN=∑j=1cKj(I−1lj)KjT.
{\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}M&=\sum _{j=1}^{c}l_{j}(\mathbf {M} _{j}-\mathbf {M} _{*})(\mathbf {M} _{j}-\mathbf {M} _{*})^{\text{T}}\\N&=\sum _{j=1}^{c}\mathbf {K} _{j}(\mathbf {I} -\mathbf {1} _{l_{j}})\mathbf {K} _{j}^{\text{T}}.\end{aligned}}}
MN​=j=1∑c​lj​(Mj​−M∗​)(Mj​−M∗​)T=j=1∑c​Kj​(I−1lj​​)KjT​.​
The Mi{\displaystyle \mathbf {M} _{i}}Mi​ are defined as in the above section and M∗{\displaystyle \mathbf {M} _{*}}M∗​ is defined as:
(M∗)j=1l∑k=1lk(xj,xk).
{(\mathbf {M} _{*})_{j}={\frac {1}{l}}\sum _{k=1}^{l}k(\mathbf {x} _{j},\mathbf {x} _{k}).}
(M∗​)j​=l1​k=1∑l​k(xj​,xk​).
A∗\mathbf A^{*}A∗ can then be computed by finding the c−1c-1c−1 leading eigenvectors of N−1M\mathbf N^{-1} \mathbf MN−1M
Predict
SW−1SB
\mathbf {S_W}^-1  \mathbf {S_B}
SW​−1SB​
A = np.linalg.inv(self.s_w).dot(self.s_b)

Caculate eigenvalues and eigenvectors
eigenvalues, eigenvectors = np.linalg.eig(A)

Sort eigenvectors from largest to smallest
idx = eigenvalues.argsort()[::-1]

Eigenvectors and eigenvalues are providing us with information about the distortion of a linear transformation: The eigenvectors are basically the direction of this distortion, and the eigenvalues are the scaling factor for the eigenvectors that describing the magnitude of the distortion.
In order to decide which eigenvector(s) we want to drop for our lower-dimensional subspace, we have to take a look at the corresponding eigenvalues of the eigenvectors. Roughly speaking, the eigenvectors with the lowest eigenvalues bear the least information about the distribution of the data, and those are the ones we want to drop.
The common approach is to rank the eigenvectors from highest to lowest corresponding eigenvalue and choose the top kkk eigenvectors.
Select the first n_components of eigenvalues and eigenvectors
eigenvalues = eigenvalues[idx][:self.n_components]
eigenvectors = eigenvectors[:, idx][:, :self.n_components]

predict
X_transformed = X.dot(eigenvectors)

supervised/adaboost.html.title: Adaboost
supervised/adaboost.html.body:
Adaboost
Objective
An AdaBoost classifier is a meta-estimator that begins by fitting a classifier on the original dataset and then fits additional copies of the classifier on the same dataset but where the weights of incorrectly classified instances are adjusted such that subsequent classifiers focus more on difficult cases.
Solution (Discrete AdaBoost)
Initialize the weights w1,1…wn,1{\displaystyle w_{1,1}\dots w_{n,1}}w1,1​…wn,1​ set to 1n{\displaystyle {\frac {1}{n}}}n1​
w = np.full(n_samples, (1 / n_samples))

while m≤Mm \leq Mm≤M do
Calculate minimum error
errm=∑i=1Nwi(m)h(−yiHm(xi))
{ err } _ { m } = \sum _ { i = 1 } ^ { N } w _ { i } ^ { ( m ) } h \left( - y _ { i } H _ { m } \left( \mathbf { x } _ { \mathbf { i } } \right) \right)
errm​=i=1∑N​wi(m)​h(−yi​Hm​(xi​))
error = sum(w[y != prediction])

Calcuate alpha
Minimize
∑iwie−yihiαt\sum_{i}w_{i}e^{-y_{i}h_{i}\alpha_{t}}i∑​wi​e−yi​hi​αt​
Using the convexity of the exponential function
∑iwie−yihiαt≤∑i(1−yihi2)wieαt+∑i(1+yihi2)wie−αt
\sum _ { i } w _ { i } e ^ { - y _ { i } h _ { i } \alpha _ { t } } \leq \sum _ { i } \left( \frac { 1 - y _ { i } h _ { i } } { 2 } \right) w _ { i } e ^ { \alpha _ { t } } + \sum _ { i } \left( \frac { 1 + y _ { i } h _ { i } } { 2 } \right) w _ { i } e ^ { - \alpha _ { t } }
i∑​wi​e−yi​hi​αt​≤i∑​(21−yi​hi​​)wi​eαt​+i∑​(21+yi​hi​​)wi​e−αt​
=(ϵt2)eαt+(1−ϵt2)e−αt
= \left( \frac { \epsilon _ { t } } { 2 } \right) e ^ { \alpha _ { t } } + \left( \frac { 1 - \epsilon _ { t } } { 2 } \right) e ^ { - \alpha _ { t } }
=(2ϵt​​)eαt​+(21−ϵt​​)e−αt​
Set it to zero to find the minimum
(ϵt2)eαt−(1−ϵt2)e−αt=0
\left( \frac { \epsilon _ { t } } { 2 } \right) e ^ { \alpha _ { t } } - \left( \frac { 1 - \epsilon _ { t } } { 2 } \right) e ^ { - \alpha _ { t } } = 0
(2ϵt​​)eαt​−(21−ϵt​​)e−αt​=0
So
αm=12log⁡(1−err⁡merr⁡m)
\alpha _ { m } = \frac { 1 } { 2 } \log \left( \frac { 1 - \operatorname { err } _ { m } } { \operatorname { err } _ { m } } \right)
αm​=21​log(errm​1−errm​​)
stump.alpha = 0.5 * math.log((1 - error_min) / (error_min + 1e-6))

For each sample i = 1,...,N, update the weight
wi(m)=wi(m)exp⁡(−αmyiHm(xi))
w _ { i } ^ { ( m ) } = w _ { i } ^ { ( m ) } \exp \left( - \alpha _ { m } y _ { i } H _ { m } \left( \mathbf { x } _ { \mathbf { i } } \right) \right)
wi(m)​=wi(m)​exp(−αm​yi​Hm​(xi​))
w *= np.exp(-stump.alpha * y * predictions)

Renormalize the weights:
Sm=∑j=1Nvj
S _ { m } = \sum _ { j = 1 } ^ { N } v _ { j }
Sm​=j=1∑N​vj​
for i=1,…,Ni = 1 , \dots , Ni=1,…,N
wi(m+1)=vi(m)/Sm
w _ { i } ^ { ( m + 1 ) } = v _ { i } ^ { ( m ) } / S _ { m }wi(m+1)​=vi(m)​/Sm​
w /= np.sum(w)

m←m+1
m \leftarrow m + 1
m←m+1
end while
Predict
H(x)=sign⁡(∑j=1MαjHj(x))
H ( \mathbf { x } ) = \operatorname { sign } \left( \sum _ { j = 1 } ^ { M } \alpha _ { j } H _ { j } ( \mathbf { x } ) \right)
H(x)=sign(j=1∑M​αj​Hj​(x))
y_pred += stump.alpha * self.H(X, stump, y_init)
y_pred = np.sign(y_pred).flatten()

supervised/support_vector_machine.html.title: Support vector machine
supervised/support_vector_machine.html.body:
Support vector machine
Reference

CS229 Lecture notes, Support Vector Machines (pdf).

Objective
We want to find the maximum-margin hyperplane that divides the points having ci=1{\displaystyle c_{i}=1}ci​=1 from those having ci=−1{\displaystyle c_{i}=-1}ci​=−1.

Solution
Notation
use parameters w, b, and write our classifier as:
hw,b(x)=g(wTx+b)
h_{w, b}(x)=g(w^{T} x+b)
hw,b​(x)=g(wTx+b)
Functional and geometric margins
define the functional margin of (w,b)(w, b)(w,b) with respect to the training example:
γ^(i)=y(i)(wTx+b)
\hat{\gamma}^{(i)}=y^{(i)}(w^{T} x+b)
γ^​(i)=y(i)(wTx+b)
if y(i)(wTx+b)>0y^{(i)}(w^{T} x+b)>0y(i)(wTx+b)>0, then our prediction on this example is correct. 
γ^\hat{\gamma}γ^​: smallest of the functional margins of the individual training examples.
γ^=min⁡i=1,…,mγ^(i)
\hat{\gamma}=\min _{i=1, \ldots, m} \hat{\gamma}^{(i)}
γ^​=i=1,…,mmin​γ^​(i)

Point A: x(i)x^{(i)}x(i)
Point B: x(i)−γ(i)⋅w/∥w∥x^{(i)}-\gamma^{(i)} \cdot w /\|w\|x(i)−γ(i)⋅w/∥w∥
Point B lies on the decision boundary, and all points x on the decision boundary satisfy the equation:
wT(x(i)−γ(i)w∥w∥)+b=0
w^{T}(x^{(i)}-\gamma^{(i)} \frac{w}{\|w\|})+b=0
wT(x(i)−γ(i)∥w∥w​)+b=0
More generally:
γ(i)=y(i)((w∥w∥)Tx(i)+b∥w∥)
\gamma^{(i)}=y^{(i)}((\frac{w}{\|w\|})^{T} x^{(i)}+\frac{b}{\|w\|})
γ(i)=y(i)((∥w∥w​)Tx(i)+∥w∥b​)
The optimal margin classifier
max⁡γ,w,bγ s.t. y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥γ,i=1,…,m∥w∥=1
\begin{aligned} \max _{\gamma, w, b} & \quad \gamma \\ \text { s.t. } & \quad y^{(i)}\left(w^{T} x^{(i)}+b\right) \geq \gamma, \quad i=1, \ldots, m \\ & \quad \|w\|=1 \end{aligned}
γ,w,bmax​ s.t. ​γy(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥γ,i=1,…,m∥w∥=1​
let’s try transforming the problem into a nicer one:
maxγ^,w,bγ^∥w∥s.t.y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥γ,i=1,...,m  \begin{aligned} max_{\hat\gamma,w,b} \quad& \frac{\hat \gamma}{\parallel w\parallel } \\ s.t. \quad &y^{(i)}(w^Tx^{(i)}+b) \geq \gamma,\quad i=1,...,m\ \end{aligned} maxγ^​,w,b​s.t.​∥w∥γ^​​y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥γ,i=1,...,m ​
We will introduce the scaling constraint that the
functional margin of w, b with respect to the training set must be 1.
γ^=1
\hat{\gamma}=1
γ^​=1
We now have the following optimization problem. The problem into a form that can be efficiently
solved. 
minγ,w,b12∥w∥2s.t.y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥1,i=1,...,m 
\begin{aligned} min_{\gamma,w,b} \quad& \frac{1}{2}\parallel w\parallel ^2 \\ s.t. \quad &y^{(i)}(w^Tx^{(i)}+b) \geq 1,\quad i=1,...,m\ \end{aligned}
minγ,w,b​s.t.​21​∥w∥2y(i)(wTx(i)+b)≥1,i=1,...,m ​
Lagrange duality
Construct the Lagrangian for our optimization problem we have:
L(w,b,α)=12∥w∥2−∑i=1mαi[y(i)(wTx(i)+b)−1]
L(w,b,\alpha )=\frac{1}{2}\parallel w\parallel ^2 - \sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i [y^{(i)}(w^Tx^{(i)}+b)-1]
L(w,b,α)=21​∥w∥2−i=1∑m​αi​[y(i)(wTx(i)+b)−1]
derivative with respect to www:
∇WL(w,b,α)=w−∑i=1mαiy(i)x(i)=0
\nabla_W L(w,b,\alpha)=w-\sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i y^{(i)}x^{(i)} =0
∇W​L(w,b,α)=w−i=1∑m​αi​y(i)x(i)=0
w=∑i=1mαiy(i)x(i)
w=\sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i y^{(i)}x^{(i)}
w=i=1∑m​αi​y(i)x(i)
derivative with respect to b:
∂∂bL(w,b,α)=∑i=1mαiy(i)=0
\frac{\partial}{\partial b}L(w,b,\alpha)=\sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i y^{(i)}=0
∂b∂​L(w,b,α)=i=1∑m​αi​y(i)=0
If we take the definition of w in Equation and plug that back into the Lagrangian, and simplify, we get:
L(w,b,α)=∑i=1mαi−12∑i,j=1my(i)y(j)αiαj(x(i))Tx(j)−b∑i=1mαiy(i)
L(w,b,\alpha)=\sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i-\frac12 \sum^m_{i,j=1} y^{(i)}y^{(j)}\alpha_i\alpha_j(x^{(i)})^Tx^{(j)}-b\sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i y^{(i)}
L(w,b,α)=i=1∑m​αi​−21​i,j=1∑m​y(i)y(j)αi​αj​(x(i))Tx(j)−bi=1∑m​αi​y(i)
But from derivative with respect to b, so we obtain:
L(w,b,α)=∑i=1mαi−12∑i,j=1my(i)y(j)αiαj(x(i))Tx(j)
L(w,b,\alpha)=\sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i-\frac12 \sum^m_{i,j=1} y^{(i)}y^{(j)}\alpha_i\alpha_j(x^{(i)})^Tx^{(j)}
L(w,b,α)=i=1∑m​αi​−21​i,j=1∑m​y(i)y(j)αi​αj​(x(i))Tx(j)
Putting this together with the constraints, we obtain the following dual optimization problem:
maxαW(α)=∑i=1mαi−12∑i,j=1my(i)y(j)αiαj⟨x(i)x(j)⟩s.t.αi≥0,i=1,...,m∑i=1mαiy(i)=0
\begin{aligned} max_\alpha \quad & W(\alpha) =\sum^m_{i=1}\alpha_i-\frac12\sum^m_{i,j=1}y^{(i)}y^{(j)}\alpha_i\alpha_j\langle	x^{(i)} x^{(j)}	\rangle\\ s.t. \quad & \alpha_i \geq 0,\quad i=1,...,m\\ & \sum^m_{i=1} \alpha_iy^{(i)}=0 \end{aligned}
maxα​s.t.​W(α)=i=1∑m​αi​−21​i,j=1∑m​y(i)y(j)αi​αj​⟨x(i)x(j)⟩αi​≥0,i=1,...,mi=1∑m​αi​y(i)=0​
Solves quadratic program in python
cvxopt
minimize:
(1/2)∗x′∗P∗x+q′∗x
(1/2)*x'*P*x + q'*x
(1/2)∗x′∗P∗x+q′∗x
subject to:
G∗x<=h
G*x <= h
G∗x<=h
A∗x=b
A*x = b
A∗x=b
P & q
∑i=1mαi−12∑i,j=1my(i)y(j)αiαj⟨x(i),x(j)⟩
\sum_{i=1}^{m} \alpha_{i}-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{i, j=1}^{m} y^{(i)} y^{(j)} \alpha_{i} \alpha_{j}\left\langle x^{(i)}, x^{(j)}\right\rangle
i=1∑m​αi​−21​i,j=1∑m​y(i)y(j)αi​αj​⟨x(i),x(j)⟩
(1/2)∗x′∗P∗x+q′∗x
(1/2)*x'*P*x + q'*x
(1/2)∗x′∗P∗x+q′∗x
P = cvxopt.matrix(np.outer(y, y) * kernel_matrix, tc='d')
q = cvxopt.matrix(np.ones(n_samples) * -1)

G & h
G∗x<=h
G*x <= h
G∗x<=h
αi≥0,i=1,…,m
\alpha_{i} \geq 0, \quad i=1, \dots, m
αi​≥0,i=1,…,m
G = cvxopt.matrix(np.identity(n_samples) * -1)
h = cvxopt.matrix(np.zeros(n_samples))

A & b
A∗x=b
A*x = b
A∗x=b
∑i=1mαiy(i)=0
\sum_{i=1}^{m} \alpha_{i} y^{(i)}=0
i=1∑m​αi​y(i)=0
A = cvxopt.matrix(y, (1, n_samples), tc='d')
b = cvxopt.matrix(0, tc='d')

unsupervised/principal_component_analysi.title: Principal component analysis
unsupervised/principal_component_analysi.body:
Principal component analysis
Principal component analysis (PCA) is a statistical procedure that uses an orthogonal transformation to convert a set of observations of possibly correlated variables (entities each of which takes on various numerical values) into a set of values of linearly uncorrelated variables called principal components.
Solution
Step 1
Caculate eigenvalues and eigenvectors of covariance_matrix(X)
eigenvalues, eigenvectors = np.linalg.eig(cov_matrix)

Step 2
Sort eigenvectors from largest to smallest
idx = eigenvalues.argsort()[::-1]

Step 3
Select the first n_components of eigenvalues
eigenvalues = eigenvalues[idx][:self.n_components]
eigenvectors = eigenvectors[:, idx][:, :self.n_components]

Predict
X_transformed = X.dot(eigenvectors)

reinforcement/q_learning.html.title: Q-learning
reinforcement/q_learning.html.body:
Q-learning
Q-learning is a model-free reinforcement learning algorithm. The goal of Q-learning is to learn a policy, which tells an agent what action to take under what circumstances
Algorithm
Qnew(st,at)←(1−α)⋅Q(st,at)+lr⋅(reward+γ⋅max⁡Q(st+1,a))
Q^{n e w}\left(s_{t}, a_{t}\right) \leftarrow(1-\alpha) \cdot Q\left(s_{t}, a_{t}\right) + lr \cdot \left( \begin{array}{cccc}reward + {\gamma} {\cdot} {\max Q\left(s_{t+1}, a\right)}\end{array}\right)
Qnew(st​,at​)←(1−α)⋅Q(st​,at​)+lr⋅(reward+γ⋅maxQ(st+1​,a)​)
current_q = self.q_table[state][action]

new_q = reward + self.discount_factor * max(self.q_table[next_state])

self.q_table[state][action] += self.learning_rate * (new_q - current_q)

deep/activations.html.title: Activation function
deep/activations.html.body:
Activation function
In artificial neural networks, the activation function of a node defines the output of that node, or "neuron," given an input or set of inputs. This output is then used as input for the next node and so on until a desired solution to the original problem is found.
Sigmoid

Equation

f(x)=11+e−x{f(x)={\frac {1}{1+e^{-x}}}}f(x)=1+e−x1​
def __call__(self, x):
    return 1. / (1. + np.exp(-x))


Derivative

f′(x)=f(x)(1−f(x)){f'(x)=f(x)(1-f(x))}f′(x)=f(x)(1−f(x))
return self.__call__(x) * (1 - self.__call__(x))


Softmax

Equation

fi(x⃗)=exi∑j=1Jexj{f_{i}({\vec {x}})={\frac {e^{x_{i}}}{\sum _{j=1}^{J}e^{x_{j}}}}}fi​(x)=∑j=1J​exj​exi​​
ndim = np.ndim(x)
if ndim == 2:
    y = np.exp(x - np.max(x, axis, keepdims=True))
    return y / np.sum(y, axis, keepdims=True)
elif ndim > 2:
    e = np.exp(x - np.max(x, axis=axis, keepdims=True))
    s = np.sum(e, axis=axis, keepdims=True)
    return e / s


Derivative

∂fi(x⃗)∂xj=fi(x⃗)(δij−fj(x⃗))\frac{\partial f_{i}(\vec{x})}{\partial x_{j}}=f_{i}(\vec{x})\left(\delta_{i j}-f_{j}(\vec{x})\right)∂xj​∂fi​(x)​=fi​(x)(δij​−fj​(x))
p = self.__call__(x)
return p * (1 - p)


TanH
Hyperbolic tangent

Equation

tanh⁡x=sinh⁡xcosh⁡x=ex−e−xex+e−x=e2x−1e2x+1{\tanh x={\frac {\sinh x}{\cosh x}}={\frac {e^{x}-e^{-x}}{e^{x}+e^{-x}}}={\frac {e^{2x}-1}{e^{2x}+1}}}tanhx=coshxsinhx​=ex+e−xex−e−x​=e2x+1e2x−1​
return 2 / (1 + np.exp(-2 * x)) - 1


Derivative

dtanh⁡dx=1−tanh⁡2\dfrac{d\tanh}{dx}=1-\tanh^2dxdtanh​=1−tanh2
return 1 - np.power(self.__call__(x), 2)


ReLU
Rectified linear unit

Equation

f(x)={0for x<0xfor x≥0{f(x)={\begin{cases}0&{\text{for }}x<0\\x&{\text{for }}x\geq 0\end{cases}}}f(x)={0x​for x<0for x≥0​
return np.where(x >= 0, x, 0)


Derivative

f′(x)={0for x<01for x≥0{f'(x)={\begin{cases}0&{\text{for }}x<0\\1&{\text{for }}x\geq 0\end{cases}}}f′(x)={01​for x<0for x≥0​
return np.where(x >= 0, 1, 0)


LeakyReLU
Leaky rectified linear unit

Equation

f(x)={0.01xfor x<0xfor x≥0{f(x)={\begin{cases}0.01x&{\text{for }}x<0\\x&{\text{for }}x\geq 0\end{cases}}}f(x)={0.01xx​for x<0for x≥0​
return np.where(x >= 0, x, self.alpha * x)


Derivative

f′(x)={0.01for x<01for x≥0{f'(x)={\begin{cases}0.01&{\text{for }}x<0\\1&{\text{for }}x\geq 0\end{cases}}}f′(x)={0.011​for x<0for x≥0​
return np.where(x >= 0, 1, self.alpha)


ELU
Exponential linear unit

Equation

f(α,x)={α(ex−1)for x≤0xfor x>0{f(\alpha ,x)={\begin{cases}\alpha (e^{x}-1)&{\text{for }}x\leq 0\\x&{\text{for }}x>0\end{cases}}}f(α,x)={α(ex−1)x​for x≤0for x>0​
return np.where(x >= 0.0, x, self.alpha * (np.exp(x) - 1))


Derivative

f′(α,x)={f(α,x)+αfor x≤01for x>0{f'(\alpha ,x)={\begin{cases}f(\alpha ,x)+\alpha &{\text{for }}x\leq 0\\1&{\text{for }}x>0\end{cases}}}f′(α,x)={f(α,x)+α1​for x≤0for x>0​
return np.where(x >= 0.0, 1, self.__call__(x) + self.alpha)


SELU
Scaled exponential linear unit

Equation

f(α,x)=λ{α(ex−1)for x<0xfor x≥0{f(\alpha ,x)=\lambda {\begin{cases}\alpha (e^{x}-1)&{\text{for }}x<0\\x&{\text{for }}x\geq 0\end{cases}}}f(α,x)=λ{α(ex−1)x​for x<0for x≥0​
λ=1.0507,α=1.67326\lambda =1.0507, \alpha =1.67326λ=1.0507,α=1.67326
self.alpha = 1.6732632423543772848170429916717
self.scale = 1.0507009873554804934193349852946
return self.scale * np.where(x >= 0.0, x, self.alpha * (np.exp(x) - 1))


Derivative

f′(α,x)=λ{α(ex)for x<01for x≥0{f'(\alpha ,x)=\lambda {\begin{cases}\alpha (e^{x})&{\text{for }}x<0\\1&{\text{for }}x\geq 0\end{cases}}}f′(α,x)=λ{α(ex)1​for x<0for x≥0​
return self.scale * np.where(x >= 0.0, 1, self.alpha * np.exp(x))


SoftPlus

Equation

f(x)=ln⁡(1+ex)f(x)=\ln \left(1+e^{x}\right)f(x)=ln(1+ex)
return np.log(1 + np.exp(x))


Derivative

f′(x)=11+e−x{f'(x)={\frac {1}{1+e^{-x}}}}f′(x)=1+e−x1​
return 1 / (1 + np.exp(-x))

deep/optimizer.html.title: Optimizer
deep/optimizer.html.body:
Optimizer
AdamOptimizer
See Kingma et al., 2014 (pdf).
Adam(short for Adaptive Moment Estimation) is an update to the RMSProp optimizer. In this optimization algorithm, running averages of both the gradients and the second moments of the gradients are used. Given parameters w(t){\displaystyle w^{(t)}}w(t) and a loss function L(t){\displaystyle L^{(t)}}L(t), where t{\displaystyle t}t indexes the current training iteration (indexed at 0{\displaystyle 0}0), Adam's parameter update is given by:

learning_rate : A Tensor or a floating point value.  The learning rate.
beta1 : A float value or a constant float tensor. The exponential decay rate for the 1st moment estimates.
beta2 : A float value or a constant float tensor. The exponential decay rate for the 2nd moment estimates.
epsilon : A small constant for numerical stability.

mw(t+1)←β1mw(t)+(1−β1)∇wL(t){\displaystyle m_{w}^{(t+1)}\leftarrow \beta _{1}m_{w}^{(t)}+(1-\beta _{1})\nabla _{w}L^{(t)}}mw(t+1)​←β1​mw(t)​+(1−β1​)∇w​L(t)
m^w=mw(t+1)1−(β1)t+1{\displaystyle {\hat {m}}_{w}={\frac {m_{w}^{(t+1)}}{1-(\beta _{1})^{t+1}}}}m^w​=1−(β1​)t+1mw(t+1)​​
self.m = self.beta1 * self.m + (1 - self.beta1) * g
m_t = self.m / (1 - self.beta1)

vw(t+1)←β2vw(t)+(1−β2)(∇wL(t))2{\displaystyle v_{w}^{(t+1)}\leftarrow \beta _{2}v_{w}^{(t)}+(1-\beta _{2})(\nabla _{w}L^{(t)})^{2}}vw(t+1)​←β2​vw(t)​+(1−β2​)(∇w​L(t))2
v^w=vw(t+1)1−(β2)t+1{\displaystyle {\hat {v}}_{w}={\frac {v_{w}^{(t+1)}}{1-(\beta _{2})^{t+1}}}}v^w​=1−(β2​)t+1vw(t+1)​​
self.v = self.beta2 * self.v + (1 - self.beta2) * np.power(g, 2)
v_t = self.v / (1 - self.beta2)

lrt:=learning_rate∗1−beta2t/(1−beta1t)lr_t := \text{learning\_rate} * \sqrt{1 - beta_2^t} / (1 - beta_1^t)lrt​:=learning_rate∗1−beta2t​​/(1−beta1t​)
variable:=variable−lrt∗mt/(vt+ϵ)variable := variable - lr_t * m_t / (\sqrt{v_t} + \epsilon)variable:=variable−lrt​∗mt​/(vt​​+ϵ)
self.w_ = self.learning_rate * m_t / (np.sqrt(v_t) self.epsilon)
return w - self.w_
